tier.item: (69) "Verborum vero figurae et mutatae sunt semper et, utcunque valuit conseutudo, mutantur.
Itaque, si antiquum sermonem nostro comparemus, paene iam quidquid loquimur figura
est, ut hac re invidere, not ut veteres et Cicero praecipue, hanc rem, et incumbere illi, non
in illum, et plenum vino non vini, et huic on hunc adulari iam dicitur et mille alia."
`Figures of speech15 have always been subject to change and are constantly in the process
of change in accordance with variations in usage. Consequently, when we compare the
speech of our ancestors with our own, almost everything we say nowadays is a special
mode of expression, i.e, variation in form. For example, we say hac re [ablative] invidere
[to grudge a thing], whereas the ancients, and especially Cicero, said hanc rem
[accusative], and incumbere illi [dative; to lean upon him], not in illum [prepositional
phrase with accusative], and plenum vino [ablative; full of wine] not vini [genitive], and
huic [dative] not hunc [accusative] adulari [to flatter]. I could mention a thousand
(69) "Verborum vero figurae et mutatae sunt semper et, utcunque valuit conseutudo, mutantur.
Itaque, si antiquum sermonem nostro comparemus, paene iam quidquid loquimur figura
est, ut hac re invidere, not ut veteres et Cicero praecipue, hanc rem, et incumbere illi, non
in illum, et plenum vino non vini, et huic on hunc adulari iam dicitur et mille alia."
`Figures of speech15 have always been subject to change and are constantly in the process
of change in accordance with variations in usage. Consequently, when we compare the
speech of our ancestors with our own, almost everything we say nowadays is a special
mode of expression, i.e, variation in form. For example, we say hac re [ablative] invidere
[to grudge a thing], whereas the ancients, and especially Cicero, said hanc rem
[accusative], and incumbere illi [dative; to lean upon him], not in illum [prepositional
phrase with accusative], and plenum vino [ablative; full of wine] not vini [genitive], and
huic [dative] not hunc [accusative] adulari [to flatter]. I could mention a thousand

"Verborum vero figurae et mutatae sunt semper et, utcunque valuit conseutudo, mutantur. Itaque, si antiquum sermonem nostro comparemus, paene iam quidquid loquimur figura est, ut hac re invidere, not ut veteres et Cicero praecipue, hanc rem, et incumbere illi, non in illum, et plenum vino non vini, et huic on hunc adulari iam dicitur et mille alia."

Figures of speech15 have always been subject to change and are constantly in the process of change in accordance with variations in usage. Consequently, when we compare the speech of our ancestors with our own, almost everything we say nowadays is a special mode of expression, i.e, variation in form. For example, we say hac re [ablative] invidere [to grudge a thing], whereas the ancients, and especially Cicero, said hanc rem

[accusative], and incumbere illi [dative; to lean upon him], not in illum [prepositional phrase with accusative], and plenum vino [ablative; full of wine] not vini [genitive], and huic [dative] not hunc [accusative] adulari [to flatter]. I could mention a thousand others.
